I have been a long time user of the Gillette Manual Fusion Razor then I bought a ProGlide Power Razor about 2 weeks before it was actually released and all I can say is WOW...this razor is by far the best razor out there today, no doubt about it...This razor makes shaving a breeze and it does not drag across your face, nick or cut you in any way...it provides the closest shave you can possibly get without going into an \\"old-school\\" barber and getting a straight razor shave..Yes, the blades are expensive but you really do \\"Get What You Pay For\\" so if you want cheap blades then expect a lousy shave with cuts and knicks..if you want an extremely close and comfortable shave with minimal effort then this is the razor for you...I recommend getting the Power Razor as it really does make a difference while shaving and it does provide a closer shave than a manual razor..Also, get rid of that crap-in-a-can gel or foam and get yourself some natural cream that you lather with a badger brush (Truefitt & Hill, Proraso, etc) and you will really see this ProGlide Power come to life..A+++ razor that I will continue to use no matter the cost of the blades...Face it, us dudes have to shave daily (or almost daily) so why go cheap and tear up your face if you do not have to..

  516. I was skeptical that Gillette was able to create another \\"best shave ever\\". More blades, more power, and whatever else their powerful marketing machine is able to drum up. However, coming from the standard Fusion line, I can't believe the difference this razor makes. Maybe it's the vibration, maybe it IS the thinner blades, but whatever it is, it works. My beard is very coarse and grows like a caveman. I can be completely smooth in the morning and by 7:00 at night, my face feels like sandpaper. Other blades, even my beloved Fusion, would pull on my face when I shaved. The ProGlide is like butter. Easily lumberjacking the thousands of mini pine trees that decorate my face. This is my first experience with a \\"powered\\" razor. I've never owned one as I thought they were gimmicky, but it seriously helps make shaving more comfortable. Perhaps this is the reason the ProGlide feels to smooth. Whatever the case, shaving has never felt better, nor lasted longer than it has with this razor. My face stays smooth ALL DAY. I do have to shave the next morning, but if I wanted to, I could go into work (like I did today) with a minor sandpaper face. However there is a cost for all of this handsomeness and it's the cost of those blades. $3.30/each from Costco. That's outrageous, but my wife does love a smooth face and I can't deny her that.

  519. I've been using Gillette since my first razor--which, incidentally, was my first razor--and they have treated me well over the years. Despite their abundantly mass-produced stock, they have been well-built (some more than others) and have stood the test of time. These new fangle-dangled battery-operated ones, however, are questionable.<br /><br />They vibrate to shake the hairs from their rested position, and, as I'm the only one who can grow a full beard in my family, getting the closest shave is very important. But more than any technology can provide, you must know your face more than the razor knows it. While Gillette's multi-blade cartridges to a great job for my face, I sometimes find myself turning the vibration off because it interrupts my study of my face. Where I know some bumps on my cheeks and chin should be, the vibration may confuse me and cause me to improperly shave and leave some spots thicker than others.<br /><br />The blades themselves are super sharp, but very expensive and a pain in the butt to clean. My sink cannot handle wads of hair (nor should any other household bathroom sink), but water is the only way to wash these suckers of the hair stubble, but it also washes away some of the lotion attached (depends which cartridges you get). In the long run, these razors will be very costly, so I'm considering doing the ol'-fashioned wet shaving.<br /><br />All in all, however, I will still keep this Fusion on hand for the comfort a Gillette shave provides, and will turn the vibration on to keep my skin massaged, and off when I end up missing some spots on my face.

  536. The shave is all about the blade and the lather. This battery operated 'thing' is a waste. Let us discuss the supposedly upgraded blade. You definitely pay for the upgrade - it is twice as much as the regular Mach 3 blade. And although you get more blades, they are very thin and are literally less stable. The buildup between the finer blades happens quicker too so I think in the long run you end up going through the Fusion ProGlide blades much quicker. And last, you can get cuts much easier. I stopped using the power feature altogether and this system is going to end up in the non-recyclable trash.<br /><br />The Mach 3 blades are fewer in number, but bulkier and seem to provide a cleaner more comfortable shave. And the blades last twice as long.<br /><br />The best shave will come from a double edged safety razor - and these blades can be recycled.<br /><br />So bottom line, the Fusion ProGlide powered or not - can glide right off the shelves into shaving history as far as I am concerned. I think the Gillette marketers make you think you are getting more because you paid more - but you are actually getting less. Proctor & Gamble stockholders and doing pretty well right now - maybe you should buy their stocks instead of the blades?<br /><br />And if you choose to be concerned about your environmental footprint - you are not helping the environment with this purchase either.

There's minimal pull on the skin, and I wound up with a nice close shave without any nicks or irritation afterwards. This is the best razor I've used yet, and while I'll probably stick to an electric for day-to-day shaving, this will work as a perfect substitute when I'm charging that one up.

When I got around to changing the battery the sealed compartment was wet and the battery appeared to be leaking and corroding in the compartment. I let the unit dry out for 2 days and put in a fresh AA and nothing, no light on the button no movement. I might have a defective one but thought I should enter a one star for others to be aware of. The unit is shorted out completely.<br /><br />I contacted Product and Gamble in response to the entry from their community manager.   561. So I really thought this was a silly gimmick when I first saw it.<br />I figured they were just trying to play to the Pulsonics popularity and try to snag some naive consumers that didn't want to shell out for the expensive electrics. The idea of putting a battery in my razor just.. I dunno, it made me laugh.<br />Men's razors seem to be getting more and more gimmicky lately.<br />I'm waiting for the 20 blade, vibrating, self lubricating, razor that compliments you on your technique as you shave.<br />Because of that I've still been scavenging Mach 3 blades (still a great razor).<br /><br />Just to be clear, I own a Pulsonic (retired) and a Panasonic Arc 5, both vibrating electrics.<br /><br />The blades on my Arc 5 were finally starting to pull hairs from being dull and I didn't have the $60 to replace them at the time, so I ordered one of these on a whim.<br />What wasn't obvious to me for some reason is that the vibration is minuscule. It's barely noticeable but it really does help the blade slice through your hairs. On most of my face it doesn't seem to make much of a difference but on my chin and upper lip where the hairs get really stiff it slid right through them. Normally those are areas where even new blades catch a bit and things get a little sketchy but this one went through without a hitch. I'm shaving my lip with a lot more confidence now... which probably means I'll be horribly wounded and disfigured soon but still, it's a nice feeling.<br /><br />Still haven't had to replace the battery after a month which is also a nice surprise since I figured they must be in bed with Duracell and had created another way to help sell AAA's to tech nerds. But nope, not even showing signs of slowing down yet.<br /><br />I still like my Arc 5 just for sheer ease of use but I'm definitely keeping this one and buying new blades for it.<br />I might finally retire my Mach 3.
  562. My son recently got one to try from Bzzagent.com site and its great.. it conforms to his face when he slides the razor over his skin its easy to use.. not confusing to how others operate.. the cartridges slide in with no problems.. Since using it , my son says its the best razor he has ever got to sample.. from a very active 23 yr old. who rarely had time to shave.. He has used it on facial hair abit longer and it still manages to shave his skin smooth. he wont buy any other razor on the market..
  563. My skin is very sensitive. It nicks easily, and I can suffer from a breakout if I end up with razorburn. The Gillette Fusion Proglide Power Razor really helps with this! I thought that the buzzing was just a gimmick until I actually tried it. I now go through one time all downstrokes, then a second time through going up, and with that little vibrating thing (doesn't it seem like that would not be a good idea, for the razor against your face to shake really quickly while you're using it?) does the trick. Not much pressure is needed for a very close shave with no nicks or burn. Definitely a great product. I took off a point because the cartridges are ridiculously expensive, but that's to be expected.
  564. As a handicapped guy I love my new fusion proglide! These new ones now come in blue and chrome whereas the ones from last year came in gold. I just bought a new one in blue assuming it would be made in France just as my gold one I got last year was. However, to my dismay, each razor can be made in France, Poland, or China. The latter is the country I never want it to be made in. I took mine back to exchange for one made in Poland. If you do not care where it is made you'd be happy buying one at random without reading where it was made on the box. I love how it feels to shave with. It definitely beats my safety razor which, I'd been shaving with daily for 3 years! Granted, the cartridges on this do cost 4 times as much. However, it is a price we must pay for luxury. Sometimes we need a little luxury in life. I consider these razors to be my toys as an adult; when I was little my toys were my inspiration and now as an &#34;adult&#34; these practical gadgets are my toys.
  565. I received this razor free from Gillette, to try and give my honest opinion. I liked the close shave I got, even without trimming my beard first.   573. Full disclosure: I received this razor from Gillette free to test and review. Starting out, this looks just like an ordinary manual razor with a swappable razor blade like so many other razors out there. The razor comes with a couple spare razors loaded in the back of the carrying base. The razor feels good to hold and I always like multiple blade razors. That is where the similarity to other razors end. The ProGlide has a ball that lets the blade swivel to contour your face. If you use a manual razor to do some contouring of your beard, goatee, or moustache, this is the razor for you. The razor glides so easily across the face I could barely feel it shaving my face. Other razors are somewhat awkward to hold to do the contouring of my beard but the ball on the ProGlide allows you to hit all of those difficult angles without having to twist your wrist into awkward positions. I like to use the razor in the shower and lather with soap. It feels very good using it in this manner. I don't use gel or foam to shave so I cannot comment on that type of shave but I would imagine it also produces a great shave. I love this razor and feel it is one of the best on the market!
  574. I received my Gillette Fusion ProGlide w/ Flexball Handle free from Gillette as part of a trial . But specifically focusing on the Flexball &#34;technology&#34;, I found it to be rather... forgettable. At no point was I shaving my face and thinking, &#34;Oh wow, this is way better now that it has this new Flexball!&#34; I've seen the commercial where they show you how well it contours to curves, and that's great and all, but I never had a problem with it before this version of the razor.

  586. I've been using the Gillette Fusion ever since it first came out and have been an enthusiastic fan. There are two things that I have always loved about it. First, it gives an incredibly close shave. Other razors cut reasonably close, the using the Fusion there are times when I can run my hand across my face and not detect even the tiniest bit of beard. Nothing but smoothness. The other thing that I love about the razor is that I have cut myself using it less than any brand of razor than I have ever used. One might think that five blades might actually increase the chances of getting cut, but this isn't the case.<br /><br />There have been several minor design changes over the past few years. They have all, however, been rather minor. Until now, that is. The new Proglide version of the Fusion is considerably different than the other versions. The main improvement is that blade now tilts back much more sharply, allowing you to shave at many more angles. I find that this allows a much better shave than before, especially around the nose. It is just easier to use than before. The other major change is that there is a heavier lubricant strip. Frankly, I'm not a big believer in lubricant strips. They don't seem to me to aid much in shaving. But if you think this matters, it is definitely true that the lubricant strip is heavier than on the old blades.<br /><br />So, if you haven't used the Fusion series, I definitely recommend doing so. It is a great razor. And if you have been using the Fusion, I would definitely recommend the upgrade to the new Fusion Proglide. It is a great improvement to an already great razor.
  587. There has been so much hype around this razor. I have seen so many advertisements on TV and on YouTube for this razor. I have never seen anything like it. I was very skeptical about buying another razor, especially after just buying the [[ASIN:B000BUUVTE Gillette Fusion Manual Razor]] and the [[ASIN:B003BVINQI Schick Hydro 5 Blade Razor]] in the past month. I was kind of drawn into the advertisements. Therefore, I was considering trying it. Then, I recently went to Target and saw the [[ASIN:B003983HO6 Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power Sneak Preview Set]]. For the price, I decided to give it a try.<br /><br />Effectiveness of The New Features:<br /><br />Of course, the thin blades are the trademark feature of this razor. I compared them to the original Fusion, and saw a noticeable difference. After shaving, I must say the combination of the small blades and the newly designed microcomb helps take in an increased amount of hair with each stroke. Of course, you will not be able to tell because of the smoothness of the shave. That microcomb truly guides the hair to the blades. After shaving, I noticed a strand my facial hair within one of the comb's teeth. The newly designed edge trimmer is a lot better than the one on the original Fusion. There is a noticeable gap in the reservoir. It is clearly big enough to take in larger amounts of hair. In addition, the reservoir make for an easier rinse.<br /><br />The Overall Pro Glide Experience:<br /><br />After my first use, I could not believe how smooth the razor shaved. The smoothness of each stroke made me feel as if I was not shaving at all because I could barely feel the razor on my face. There was no tugging or pulling. Using an increased amount of shaving cream only enhances the \\"Gliding\\" experience. For Gillette to say the razor is \\"designed to glide\\" is an understatement. I must admit, shaving with a power razor felt a little awkward, though. To prove the effectiveness of the Pro Glide compared to the other razors, I temporarily went back to using the Schick Hydro 5 Blade Razor because the preview set only has one usable cartridge. I actually felt the blades against my skin. The shave did not feel anywhere near as comfortable as it felt using the Pro Glide. Not to mention, I nicked myself. The Pro Glide wins by a landslide. For those, who are looking for a new razor, which will give you an unbelievably comfortable shave, look no further than the Pro Glide. While shaving, you will realize that is EXACTLY what it does. Believe the hype!!! You will receive a shave like you never have before.<br /><br />Tip: Since the razors are expensive, users can prolong the life of the razor by shaking all excess water out of the razor to the point, which the razor is dry. Put some rubbing alcohol on the razor. Next, place the razor into a plastic bag, so moisture can be kept out. I have used the same razor, which came with the [[ASIN:B003983HO6 Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power Sneak Preview Set]]. I have been using the same razor for at least, 15 times. The lubrastrip is STILL green. Therefore, I still have more use of the same razor.Schick Hydro 5 Blade Razor because the preview set only has one usable cartridge. I actually felt the blades against my skin. The shave did not feel anywhere near as comfortable as it felt using the Pro Glide. Not to mention, I nicked myself. The Pro Glide wins by a landslide. For those, who are looking for a new razor, which will give you an unbelievably comfortable shave, look no further than the Pro Glide. While shaving, you will realize that is EXACTLY what it does. Believe the hype!!! You will receive a shave like you never have before. Tip: Since the razors are expensive, users can prolong the life of the razor by shaking all excess water out of the razor to the point, which the razor is dry. Put some rubbing alcohol on the razor. Next, place the razor into a plastic bag, so moisture can be kept out. I have used the same razor, which came with the [[ASIN:B003983HO6 Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power Sneak Preview Set]]. I have been using the same razor for at least, 15 times. The lubrastrip is STILL green. Therefore, I still have more use of the same razor.

  590. I was not a big fan of the previous Gillette fusion because it irritated my skin and gave me very uncomfortable shaves. I thought that this one would be an improvement and I was excited about getting the pro glide version. Like a dummy I didn't test it first and got the bulk set from Costco. This is by far the worst razor ever. There was no gliding at all, it was more like grinding. It irritated the hell out of my skin and it was the most uncomfortable shave ever. It felt as if it was pulling each hair out of my face and I was bleeding everywhere. At first I thought that OK maybe its was this specific blade I was using so I got another blade, the same. The next morning I pulled out an old unused single blade disposable I had for emergencies and it was much more comfortable then this one. I absolutely hate this razor, I ended up giving away the other unused blades. I had to go back to my old Gillette Mach3 disposable which were 100x better then this. Few days later, I went out and got the Shick Hydro 3 blade, now this is a great razor. Felt great. Best shave ever. This did everyting that the Pro glide promised to do. I had no irritation of the skin and the shave was very comfortable and close. I would NOT recommend this razor at all. I guess maybe my skin is too sensitive, but I thought that this was supposed to the best for sensitive skin...WRONG. Do yourself a favor and don't spend you money on this overpriced crap. Get the Shick Hydro or any other disposable razors, they will do a better job.
  591. I tried every razor on the market starting with the Gillette sensor 2 blade when I first started shaving at around 14-15 years of age. The truth is that I kept on buying into the newer razors that came out thinking they were better but that was always not the case. So I'll briefly compare this to the other razors I've tried and tell you a honest view of mine about why this deserves only one star and which razors are better. Firstly, when I started shaving the Gillette sensor excel 2 blade was excellent and provided a good shave with less to no irritation at all when used with a shave gel. The sensor 3 blade was a little closer and just as comfortable as the two blade. Thats all I have to say about that. The Mach 3 then came out which did seem to be a better razor and provided a closer shave with out much irritation so it was a winner. Then Mach 3 power nitro came out and the power aspect felt good but the results was basically the same. So all in all the Mach 3 manual and power were better than the Sensor excel 2 and 3 blade razors up to now. Schick then came out with the quattro 4 blade(the original first one) which was Ok and provided a good close shave but I still decided to stick with the comfort of the Mach 3. So up till now the Mach 3 was my razor of choice. Now the story changes a bit: I received a free sample of the fusion power and at first I thought it was the best razor because of the first few close shaves it provided. I got over excited and bought a 8 pack refill for the fusion power thinking I would never use anything else. BAD DECISION!!!! My clear unirritated skin became red and irritated after continuing to use the fusion power. At first I thought maybe my skin is changing as I'm getter older so it's my skin's fault. I would get ingrown hairs and it was then embarrassing to go out. I lost all my self confidence and started staying more reserved. I tried various skin treatments to rid of the irritations and redness but nothing would work. The problem with the fusion was that the blades would only last about 3 shaves and then irritate the hell out of your face. ONE DAY I DECIDED IT WAS TIME TO TRY ANOTHER RAZOR. I then bought the Schick Quattro Titanium and boy was it a much less irritating shave with more comfort and the same closeness as the fusion. It was much much better than the fusion because of the titanium coating and the blades last forever. They would stay sharp for months and wouldn't clog if a shave gel was used.(I know people complain that it clogs but with a light foaming shave gel like Anthony Logistics or Zirh it doesn't). Now Hydro 5 vs. Fusion Proglide Hydro 5 came out first and since the schick quattro titanium was my razor of choice I had to try the Hydro 5. At first I liked it, the gel strip felt gooey but washed off easy with warm water. The shave was not as close as I would have wanted. The hydro 5 missed a few parts on the neck area and the under nose area because of the huge cartridge. Still I kept on using it since it came with 2 refills anyway. The gel strip lasted longer than fusion but not as long as quattro titanium. Fusion Proglide: I bought the sneak peek package just to try the razor before it came out and all I can say is AWFULLLLLL!!!!!!! This time I couldn't even get one good shave from this crap. Turns shaving into gliding my A$$!!!! It's very uncomfortable to use and does not glide at all.I will admit that it provides a very close shave but that irriates my face a lot. So the fusion proglide is the worst razor I've ever used so far. The cartridge lasts only like two shaves and the refills are more expensive than a full tank of gasoline(mind the exaggeration but you know what I mean). Final verdict: Gillette just tweaks their razors a bit makes false claims and sells their refills for a lot of money to fool the consumers. They are nothing but marketing now. Up until the Mach 3 they were my razor brand but the fusion and fusion proglide are nothingbut scams. They look cool but I think they are face wreckers. Then again I have sensitive skin so I understand people with thicker beards and normal skin probably love Gillette razors but I have to address the sensitive skin shavers out there and Gillette razors should be avoided by them unless they want a irritated face. The hydro 5 lost because of the huge razor head and strip making it less precise. Also the skin guards on the hydro irritate more than help. So Schick Quattro Titanium is the razor of choice for my sensitive skin. It will not clog with Zirh or Anthony Logistics shave gel and causes no irritation. The blade lasts long and refills are reasonable price, it has the single edging blade which is better than hydro 5 flip trimmer which just irritates. Sorry for long review but I just had to share my experience.
  592. Clean, close, comfortable shave but my $14 battery operated Braun (including batteries) travel shaver works as good or better. I'm not looking for a religious experience when I shave - just smooth skin without irritation, nicks or cuts. The Proglide gives a good but not superior result, and Gillette's instructions for an optimal shave require too much prep time. Also, Gillette hints that the razor may dull after 5 shaves. It does and the \\"special lubricating strip\\" wears out sooner. Frequent razor replacement in addition to the cost of a better quality shave cream is ridiculously expensive. I'll continue to use the Braun (which has a surprisingly good shave block) for daily shaving, and save the Proglide for trimming my sideburns and neckline where it excels.

  596. I really didn't want to like this razor, the ongoing gimmickry has become increasingly annoying. However I have to admit this razor gives a really comfortable shave. The ergonomics are the best I've come across, well balanced, correctly angled head, substantial weight with battery installed. The five-blade cluster is more than just gimmickry, it provides a wider shaving area, which is more stable as you shave. The vibrating gimmick is just that, however. It seems to add nothing to the shave and it completely eliminates any tactile feedback, which I find necessary for a good shave. New blades are quite expensive, usually $3-$4 each, pretty steep but you may find the comfort of the shave is worth it (I'm still unsure). To sum up, pass on the powered version and go with the cheaper 'manual' version and be prepared to pay a lot for new blades.

I couldn't quite figure out why you'd want a battery operated razor, but I was surprised to find that it really makes a difference. I really can't see any movement of the razor when I look at it turned on, but it works very well. The razor itself has nice rubberized grips which help make sure it doesn't slip out of your hands. The new Proglide is smooth and did the job without punishing my face. I can shave in the shower without a mirror and the razor glides gently over my face without missing a spot or nicking my skin. If there is one downside to using Gillette Fusion razors it would be the high cost of replacement blades. I suppose one must pay the price for quality and innovation.

  604. I've used a Schick Quattro for years, and figured it was time to get a new razor. It looks nice, but that's about it.<br /><br />The handle gets incredibly slippery. I find myself having to thoroughly dry it and my hands multiple times while shaving. I don't remember having this issue with other razors.<br /><br />They made this razor very flexible, I'm guessing so that it will follow the contours of your neck better (maybe in the crook of the neck yes, but no benefits around the Adam's apple). I leave stubble on my face most of the time, and shave my neck clean, so I need to get a straight line under my jaw and chin. This razor is just to floppy for that. I need a firmer razor, one that doesn't flop around as much at the head. This one is what I imagine it would be like to shave with a wet sponge.<br /><br />I also haven't noticed a difference in closeness of shave, nor a reduction in the number of times I have to go across a given area.<br /><br />I'll be going back to my old Schick Quattro. I hope they keep making blades for it…

  610. Some of us may recall that the &#34;tool&#34; our fathers used to shave with was called a straight razor. They sharpened this &#34;tool&#34; on a leather strap every so often. (Another use was when an older brother had his rear tanned when he got out of line!)<br /><br />To use a straight razor, the angle where the razor met the skin for shaving was very important. An incorrect angle and the skin would be cut. The other item of importance was the amount of pressure applied to the razor during the shaving. Too much force and a cut usually resulted. Too little force and hair was not shaved off.<br /><br />The safety razor came into being when a guy named Gillette devised a &#34;tool&#34; to eliminate the need to hold the razor at a precise angle to shave the face. Many others then came out with safety razors.<br /><br />Today's safety razors, as I have stated is only a &#34;tool&#34; for shaving. The final shave results depend on the expertise of the user. For most this expertise is easily acquired but for a few they never get the hang of it.<br /><br />The secret of getting a great shave depends on the pressure one applies to the shaving &#34;tool&#34;, your safety razor.<br /><br />Gillette produces great shaving &#34;tools&#34;.. every one is better than the one before it!
  611. I give five stars for the interest of all mankind, I just had the closest shave EVER (and I have had many, including from straight-blade razors). My skin feels so soft and smooth like a baby's skin and most important of them all, no blood anywhere. I have a Mach 3 with which every shave made my face red with blood, like it was some battlefield of some medieval European country.<br />Today is the first time since I took birth that my shave did not give me any cuts, neither did I feel any irritation. I plan on shaving everyday just so I could use this razor.<br />If you can afford it, then don't think twice, just click on \\"Buy with 1-click\\".
  612. Using it for 3 weeks now, I would say I am happy with not super excited though. This is not a revolutionary product. Many people seem to complain about the vibrations. I would say it gives a feeling of so called &#34;glide&#34; as it suppresses friction feel and makes it feel smooth. Just a feeling no real effort has been taken to reduce blade to skin friction over other products in this range. Overall its a good upgrade over disposable razors but nothing great compared to other products in this league.
  613. Great blade. I've been using Gillette Atras for 20+ years and I thought it was time to test out other options. What an upgrade! The vibrating blade really does help and I liked precision trimmer for getting a clean shave below the nose. Replacement blades are a few dollars more expensive than some other options I tried, but it's worth it to me.
  614. At first was skeptical of the vibrating shaver and still not quite sure of it's contribution but I have to say that I haven't had a shave quite like this before. Hands down the smoothest shave ever and my sensitive skin has been deprived of it's usual razor burn. Good buy and goodbye.
  615. Honestly I was skeptical of Gillette just creating another gimmick cartridge to take our money, but as far as their other razors are concerned, this one really is great. I can only compare it to other Gillette razors, but this is by far their best. I was fine with my old regular Fusion, but this you cannot even feel the hairs being cut, and gets my face super smooth. I still get minor razor burn on my neck sometimes, but I can't imagine another big-brand-name razor like this being this smooth. I was really considering the safety razor route, but now I may not have to.
  616. During my first run with this I saw that it was able to glide and shave all my facial hair. But during the second run I saw that it start to run over my facial hair.   617. Hi, I received this razor for Christmas and was shocked at how easy the shave went. I have never been big on a battery operated razor because I thought it was a waste. Not true. It has been a pleasure to have a good clean shave that is so effortless. I am happy with this razor.

I have to be just as thorough with this handle and I find that a shave takes just as long for maybe a slightly improved result. Finally, there is an extra blade on the top of the unit for precision trimming. I am finding that to be quite useful in working under the lip and for sideburns.

It's not the best. The best up to this point from my experience is the Merkur Model 180. Gillette's quality seems to have slipped, as the blades do not keep their sharp edges long enough. I can only get about 7 shaves out of one cartridge.   631. I was in need of a new razor. I have sensitive skin and I'm always complaining about not getting a close enough shave without tearing my face up, so when I saw the commercial for Proglide I decided to give it a go. It's sleek and lightweight and easy to use, which is a bonus. I'll say this, it does give me a clean, close shave; but only if I space out its usage. Thankfully, I only shave a few days a week, considering that it is not a requirement with my line of work that I be clean shaven. When I've waited a few days before using, the Proglide is a dream. It glides over my face and takes with it unwanted hair, leaving a smooth aftermath that I thoroughly enjoy. Sadly, I've noticed that if I shave two days in a row my skin gets irritated and the shave is nowhere near as close. I know that some consider the battery operated vibration to be a mere gimmick, but having used a razor with the same capability for years I have found that my shave is always closer WITH the vibration, and I'm quick to replace the battery because of that. Sure, it can make a shave more expensive in the long run, but it's worth it (as far as I'm concerned). When the vibration is on, the razor pulls at your face for a closer shave, which is pretty neat. All in all, I like this product. It delivers most of the time; I just wish it were always.

They long ago reached the technical apex for shaving with multi blade technology, after this it's all sales pitch unless you hear they've got a laser model. I don't fault Gillette for trying to do makeovers, look what happened to Polaroid and Kodak when they tried to continue without innovation or change. Make sure you have (as I did) or can still get blades for this. Comes in a nice box that's a good holder for day to day. I didn't rate it a 5 because, honestly, the vibrator is a novelty where form over function is a sales tool, not an improvement in shaving.

  644. First off, yes I am a woman. I never thought I would use a man's razor because of the fact I have been a loyal consumer of Schick Quattro For Women.   645. I confess I'm an electric razor user but when by four year old electric gave out my first thought was not to impulse buy a new one but try a high end blade razor until I make my electric choice. This razor has the sharpest blades I've ever used. The battery powered viration feature lessens the friction for sure. The closeness of course is phenomonal. My son told me about the '5 week' blade ad. I used this exactly nine times and you know exactly when you've shaved your last shave with a blade. It was on the ninth shave (today). For me that's the limit. I could feel the friction increase significantly. For me the blade cost wouldn't be high because it's a great price/qualty/value. Blade shaving is not for me but if it were I'd use this. no doubt.<br /><br />12/19/12 Update: I realized that the buzzy motor thing is just a gimmick. I can tell you that for me it actualy caused more friction and micro cuts. When I tuend it off I got a much better shave. Still, after about 7 to 9 shaves max, the blade is done for me. The blaes are micro thn and just don't hold up for my wiskers. I still think the expense is a lot but not so much if you really are into shaving and willing to shell out the dough. I'm now mostly using my electric wet with a great gel I've found \\"Nivea sensitive skin\\". OT but for wet electric shaving the exact right gel makes all the difference and other's I've used were horrible (ie. \\"King of Shaves\\"). I alternate the electric with Gillete Mach III, which I would say are almost as good as these blades.

  647. Smoooooooooth now, like a baby's bottom.

  649. I really believe the Gillette Fusion Proglide Power Razor is the best razor I have ever used. I am able to shave with the grain and against the grain on my neck and face without any irritation or razor burn. Where I see the greatest difference between this razor and razors like Mach 3 and the Gillete Power Fusion is when I shave my head. I have been shaving my head for 10 years and I remember the first time I used the Gillette Proglide on my head, I couldn't believe how baby skin soft my head felt. Over these 10 years I tried just about every new razor there was on my head. I shave my head once a day and sometimes twice. On a rare occasion I even shaved it three times. I shave my entire head usually twice with the grain and twice or more against the grain using a moderate degree of pressure and I can truthfully say it leaves my head the smoothest of anything I ever tried. I have had no razor burn or cuts with this Power Proglide razor. I have used many types of shaving creams with the Proglide razor like Nivea for Sensitive Skin, various types of Edge gell, Aveeno, Aloe Vera Gel, Shaving Secret oil, hair conditioner, bottled shampoo, moisturizers, shaving mug soap with brush and even dial bath soap brushed into a lather with my shaving brush. I can honestly say that there is not too much difference with using these shaving gels/soaps with the Gillette Power Proglide.The product that I found to give me the closest smooth head with the Power Proglide is the Nivea Shave Gel for Sensitive Skin. I can usually get about 5 complete head shaves (several times with the grain and against the grain) and beard shaves with one razor before I need to replace it. The trimmer is quite helpful to trim around and outline my beard, goatee, mustache and even the occasional eyebrow. The only negative for this razor is the price. If you want the most baby skin smooth head and face, you will want to try this razor.
  650. If you're using this product daily, it's probably just fine, although the vibration with the battery seems gimmicky. I don't think it adds anything. However, for a 2-3 day growth, I found that it pulls on my skin badly, so I found it no better then earlier Gillette models, and really, not any better than some disposable blades.

  655. This is an excellant razor. I bought it for my husband and he really likes it. Gets close dry shave.
  656. Let me start out by saying that if you're absolutely settled on a cartridge razor system, this or the regular Fusion Proglide will probably fit the bill just fine. As far as multi-blade razors go, this is the most comfortable shave I've experienced from one.<br /><br />With that said, here's the deal. For the longest time I simply used regular old Gillette Mach 3 disposables and bought some more every time I ran out. They never gave me a great shave, but I chocked that up to my sensitive skin and thought razor burn and bumps were unavoidable. I figured at the very most I'd need to simply find a better shaving foam/gel, but I never did find it. Finally, I decided to 'upgrade', and bought one of these at CVS for $10.<br /><br />The Fusion Proglide does offer superior performance over standard disposables, of course. In terms of cartridge razor 'systems', this is as good as it gets. I don't think that the 'Power' model is necessary, although it's what I got. The vibrating feature can sometimes feel nice, but most of the time I just shave with it normally.<br /><br />Here's why I say it turned me off of cartridge systems forever. I went from standard disposables to this, and instead of getting a lot better shave and/or saving money, I got a marginally better shave for quite a bit of money. The razor itself is only about $10, but cartridges are currently $32 for 8 cartridges on Amazon! At the very most - and I think I'm being a bit too generous here - this is a 2-month supply, assuming each cartridge lasts a week which I highly doubt. That's at least $192 a year just on cartridges! (Although, I believe you can use regular Fusion Proglide cartridges, although they aren't much cheaper).<br /><br />Now, I don't mean to sound like a salesman here, but I do have another suggestion. After realizing I couldn't justify $200 a year on cartridges, I was absolutely sure there had to be a cheaper way to shave that didn't involve an electric razor which doesn't get close enough. Amazon \\"Top Rated\\" directed me to an old-school Merkur double-edged safety razor, and I read up. I'm not trying to sell you guys a Merkur. Buy whatever safety razor floats your boat, but hear this out: 100 razor blades for $10. Razor blades that are sharper and probably last just as long as the cartridges (and perform better), for much, much cheaper. Even if they each only last 3-4 days, that's still a years supply for around $10 as opposed to $192. I'm no math major, but I think that's a savings of about $182.<br /><br />I got tired of paying for a cartridge system that doesn't shave as well as an old-school safety razor, irritates my face, and costs literally hundreds of dollars a year. It didn't make sense to me. In a week or two of using a DE razor, I've made irritation literally a thing of the past. The thing glides along the face, hardly feeling like it's touching you until you realize the hair is gone. Honestly, it's an epiphany that I can't keep quiet about. Especially if you've got sensitive skin, make the switch and save a lot of money.
  657. I just received my Gillette Fusion Proglide power razor today. I allowed 2 days of growth so I could really put this razor to the test. The razor cut so smooth and clean it was as if it just wiped the hair away. This is my new favorite razor.

On the other side I shaved with the vibration OFF. It was still very effortless and a super smooth shave, but it wasn't AS close as using the vibration. Moral of the story, if you like a smooth effortless shave, every time, us the vibration.

  674. I was given the chance to check out a Fusion ProGlide Power thanks to a freebie from Gillette. I must admit I was a bit skeptical about the addition of the vibration from the handle doing anything to help in the shaving process going into it. After giving it a shot and trying both with it on and off, I feel it does help to stand the hairs up a bit better and really helps the blade slide across the face easier.<br /><br />While not something we generally think about, this handle has a nice weight to it. This helps both in controlling the blade in your hand and also makes it feel less cheap than other blades. The added weight also helps in pulling the blade across the face and when controlling it around areas like sideburns. The blade on the Fusion ProGlide slides right through hairs without the tugging I often had with other cheap blades. I don't end up with the redness on my neck like I use to. While one can use the front of the razor for straight cut areas like sideburns, the trimmer on the backside of the head does a better job at making a straight line and is easier to tell where you're cutting. Overall it makes shaving an easier experience that's less painful.<br /><br />After giving the Fusion ProGlide Power a shot, I'm sold and have made the switch from my previous razor (Mach 3). It does the job better with a smoother shave with less pulling than before. Shaving isn't something we enjoy doing but this blade makes it easier to get it done and get on with your day looking great.

After having tried out the product I want share the pros and cons related to the Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power Razor and its blades. Overall the razor is the best razor that I have ever used. The razor blades are excellent, high-quality razor blades that I would recommend to everyone.<br /><br />The pros are as follows:<br />* The trimmer provides a good shave with an easy to snap on razor blade that will not pop-off like other shaving blades due to an advanced locking mechanism. Which is great as unlike other razors the blade will not pop off when tapping it on the sink to clean out the stubble.<br />* I have very thick stubble that dulls blades after one or two shaves. The Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power blades last me through a whole work week.<br />* They have five + one sharp blades that are easy to clean via simply tapping them and the stubble falls out from between the blades unlike with other blades.<br />* Also, the blades do not bend easily or get out of shape which makes them work better for longer.<br />* They have a sixth blade on the top for shaving your neck, what an awesome feature! This razor has by far given me the best shave of any blade.<br />* The Power razor simply massages your face; though, I do not believe that it actually helps with cutting the stubble.<br />* The razor feels great in your hand with its rubber grips and perfect size.<br /><br />As for the cons, I cannot think of any.

I'v gone on to refills and the battery shows no signs of giving out. Not sure how many shaves it's good for but a AAA Duracel is holding steady. It gets wet, it doesn't get slick. It's very well balanced. I can grasp it between my thumb and a finger and feel like I have the ultimate control for those sensitive areas. Now for years I've been seeing these newfangled battery operated razors. \\"What's a little vibration going to do,\\" I've said to myself. Who would've thought, but that little vibration helps this razor cut through my rather coarse facial hair like the proverbial hot knife through butter. As I mentioned, I don't shave every day. I've gone for a week at a time not shaving, where in the past I would've dreaded getting around to the irritation I knew my old razors would cause while trying to get through that growth.   733. This razor is typical Gillette quality. Many of the features of this razor are slight refinements of previous designs. I found that the design of the cartridge made it easy to rinse while shaving. As far as I know, the micro-comb is the only thing that is different between the power and manual blades, which makes sense.<br /><br />The grip is positive and tacky. It holds blades securely and releases them easy. No complaints there.<br /><br />Overall it is a fine razor package, and the powered handle does offer some marginal improvement over the manual version.<br /><br />Note: I received a free razor to test from a program run by Gillette

But after using it, I don't know if the vibrating helped the shave but it couldn't have hurt. It was a strange feeling on my skin but it was a close smooth shave. I hope that the razor has a long life span because it's a joy to shave with.
  737. I was skeptical about the vibrating \\"Power\\" that leads to a closer shave. But it truly gets great results. Very smooth - no nicks. Love the new design of this razor and I highly recommend this.
  738. Hi Guys and Gals,<br /><br />So I received this free from gillette to try controlling my facial hair and you know what it works! But the real question is how well does it work? Answer: Pretty darn well. I've used a few different razors including all the past versions of the Proglide and it provides one of the best close shaves I've found. It's smooth and the gel strip built into the blade really does help. I just wish I could say that this version was leaps and bounds better than the previous ones. Most people wont be able to notice a difference between this and any of the previous incarnations of the Proglide line. Does this mean you shouldn't pick it up when you need a new razor? No, it just means you should wait until you nned a new razor or until you see it on sale.<br /><br />Overall it's provides a good clean shave and does everything you'd want from a razor, it just isn't a noticeable improvement over any of the previous versions.
  739. I've been a long time user of the Gillette Mach3 razor. I received the a free Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power razor via a program run by Gillette. I found that it performed as well as the Mach3 but not noticeably better.<br /><br />This razor has a battery powered vibrating action activated by a power button. I'm not sure what the purpose is since I didn't notice any difference with it on or off.<br /><br />Since the Fusion ProGlide Power is more expensive than the Mach3 and I don't see any major difference in the final result, I will stick with the Mach3.
  740. I used to always use the Gillette disposable razors, so when I got a sample of the \\"fusion proglide power razor\\" I was excited to try it. I must say the difference is totally noticeable. I start getting a stubble almost after couple of hours of shaving. This one gives me such a smooth shave that I can keep stubble at bay for at least a day. Absolutely no nicks and cuts, glides like silk on my face. I don't need to apply any after shave lotions too since this worked out great for my sensitive skin. Its a bit on the expensive side, but with all the coupons that gillette gives, I think I will stick to using this one in the future
  741. I've tried many razors over the years, but I keep going back to my Panasonic shaver. But thanks to a program run by Gillette, I had a chance to try the Gillette Fusion ProGlide for free. So, since it had power (like an electric shaver), I thought this might be a nice middle ground - and it was!<br /><br />The vibrations in handle won't overpower you - it is just right and does give the sense of having an electric shaver in your hand. The handle is easy to grip when wet thanks to the ridges on both side, and the blade cartridge pops on and off with the snap of a release button. Plus, the slightly larger size of the base of the handle adds a little weight, which is nice. This helps balance your hand as you carefully glide over your stubble with the sharp cartridge.<br /><br />The LED power button may be a little too bright for me in the morning (no bright lights, please), but it isn't loud like my shaver, so no worries of waking the house accidentally with the buzz-saw sound of my shaver. The power does add something unique to the shaving experience, I can't exactly describe it, but it just adds something to the experience.<br /><br />I like the Gillette Fusion ProGlide because it gets me a closer shave than my electric razor. But personally I am always running late so I know I will be falling back on my shaver . But if you don't mind the very bright power button, this would be well worth a try for a regular razor user.
  742. Through a promotion with Gillette I received a free Fusion pro-glide power handle razor. I have to say I really liked the razor it provided a very close shave and I really enjoyed this razor. The larger handle made for easy shaving and I usually drop my razor's and haven't had that issue with this razor.
  743. I received the Gillette ProGlide Power Handle and one razor cartridge as a promotion from Gillette.<br /><br />The handle is similar to others, but has a few new features. With a slightly larger handle it has a nice feel in your hand. I haven't tried it in the shower but it certainly is a convenient feature. With an auto shutoff feature it will turn off the razor if it is accidentally left on or turned on. The vibration from the handle definitely helps to reduce the drag or pull on the beard.<br /><br />The cartridge is a definite improvement. Not sure if it is the micro comb, the thinner blades or the suspension system, but it really delivered a great shave. I will need to see if the cartridge lasts a whole month as it is stated.<br /><br />I think this is a great buy, especially for those that have sensitive skin and get razor burn easily like I generally do.
  744. I received a free sample of the Gillette Fusion ProGlide to review. I must tell you that this is by far the best razor on the market. The design is perfect! The only complaint that I could possibly come up with is that the shave is so close I actually got a pretty nasty ingrown hair. A small price to pay for a great shave. Like most men I hate shaving and I do it as little as possible. This razor has actually added another day between shaves for me. Awesome. The handle fits perfectly in my hand allowing more control and a better shave. Thank you a great product.
  745. I like the razor. it feels like i got a better shave and the vibration definitely helps when cleaning the blade.
  746. I was provided this gilette razor through a promotion, and I could not be more pleased with it. This is a solid razor.
  747. I'm a Schick Quattro user, and have been for a lot of years, but Gillette sent me a free Fusion ProGlide Power through a promotional program, so I figured I'd give it a try.<br /><br />My shaving needs might be a bit different from most guys in that I have a beard, but I shave my head. The head shaving is what has kept me a Quattro user for so many years, as the Quattro has protective wires that keep me from inadvertently scalping myself. The Gillette razor has no such wires, but I'm a daring guy, so I gave it a shot, and was very impressed. I'd been lazy about shaving my head, so I had about ten days of growth going on. Normally, I would have to use a set of electric clippers before shaving this much growth, but the Gillette blades are pretty open, so I skipped straight to shaving. I got a great shave and the blades didn't clog at all. Having attempted this and failing miserably with the Quattro, I was amazed that the blades rinsed clean without any real effort on my part.<br /><br />The performance on my neck was also impressive. I normally shave my neck with a Braun electric due to issues with razor burn, but I didn't experience any razor burn with the Fusion ProGlide.<br /><br />Does the powered handle make a difference? For me, the answer was yes. Gillette had previously sent me a standard Fusion ProGlide handle to sample and I was not impressed. With the non-powered version, I had to go over a lot of areas multiple times to get a smooth shave, which created irritation. The power handle provided a much better shave for me without having to repeatedly drag blades across the same area.<br /><br />Altogether, the features of this handle and blade combo provided me with a great shave. Oh, and if you're wondering whether I missed the protective wires of the Quattro, that's an affirmative. I expect the scab behind my ear to be gone any day now, with minimal scarring.
  748. First I have to say that I received this razor as part of a promotion from Gillette. The package arrived with the razor, a nice holder, and one blade cartridge. My first impression was 'I wonder why this thing takes batteries'. The razor handle itself felt very sturdy, much more so than other reusable razor handles I've tried. I looked forward to giving it a try.<br /><br />I should also say that I generally use an electric razor during the week, and then use a traditional razor on Sundays after I've skipped shaving all weekend. The electric razor doesn't handle the few days of growth. So my first try of the Gillete ProGlide was on ~3 days worth of beard. Wow was I impressed! With the typical disposable or cartridge razors I always have problems with them getting clogged. The ProGlide handled this quite well, I presume the vibration helps the blades stay clear. The vibration also seems to help the blades move much more smoothly through the hairs with less pressure. I was very impressed with this razor!
  749. I have been using the Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power razor for three weeks now and have been pleasantly surprised by the results. To give some background, I have a tough, thick beard that grows back fairly quickly. I work in an industry where it is important to maintain a clean-cut look. I have found that electric razors have not been able to provide a close enough shave for me and have been using the Gillette Mach3 for the past several years.<br /><br />I had sampled the Gillette Fusion Power when it first released and was extremely dissatisfied with the experience, so I returned to my Mach3. I found that the lubricated strip wore out after the first use, the micropulses from the battery were weak and ineffective, and water leaked into the battery compartment causing damage to the product. As a result, I had very low expectations from the Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power.<br /><br />I received a sample Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power handle and cartridge through a program sponsored by Gillette. It appears that most of the negative issues that I had encountered on the Gillette Fusion Power have been addressed. I didn't expect that there could be any noticeable improvement to my shaves with 5 blade technology, battery powered micropulses, and a lubristrip but I couldn't have been more wrong. The Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power razor delivered the smoothest shave I have ever had - not only on the first use but also after repeated uses. I could really feel the battery powered micropulses in conjuction with the microcomb lift the hairs up and guide them in a uniform direction for a closer cut. The lubristrip allowed for smooth strokes and as a result, the razor was gliding effortlessly. The mineral oil from the lubristrips also left my skin feeling soft and irritation-free. The power of 5 blades meant that I did not have to repeat my strokes. With all these efficiencies, there is literally no friction (ie. no tugging and pulling) or discomfort. The razor glides effortlesslyand also provides a very close shave - which is exactly what I have been looking for.<br /><br />The ergonomic design of the handle made it easy to grip but because of the large size of the 5-blade cartridge, I still found the product difficult to maneuver around the tight spots around the sideburns and below the nose. The product advertises a precision trimmer, which is supposed to help with these areas, but I'm not sure it completely addresses the problem with maneuvering such a large cartridge. I have noticed that I have been becoming more adept with repeated use, so perhaps it is an acquired skill but it is definitely a noticeable different handle in comparison to the Mach3. The handle also has an automatic shutoff feature if the battery power is left on after 8 minutes. I did not use this feature, but think it is a good safeguard in case someone does accidently leave the power on. When I had used the Gillette Fusion Power, I had noticed damage to the battery compartment due to water leakage. Fortunately, they have addressed that issue in this product. When I opened up the handle, there were no traces of water having leaked into the battery compartment.<br /><br />I tested the razor under multiple conditions over the past three weeks: 1 day shave, 3 day shave, and 1 week shave. In each situation, the result was a smooth, close shave. With the 1 day shave, where I had limited hair regrowth, I did experience a few nicks below the nose but because of the mineral oil from the lubristrip, I could not even notice the cuts. Normally on the 3 day shave, I have significant regrowth by the end of the 2nd day but because of the closer shave from the Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power, I didn't notice the same level of regrowth until the middle of the 3rd day! The product was also able to handle a 1 week shave with the same level of effortlessness. Normally, with my Mach3, the hairs would get stuck inside the blades and I have to make repeat strokes over the same areas, but with the Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power, I was able to still complete the shave in single, deep strokes.<br /><br />My only complaint is that the lubristrip has started to wear out and appear white after 4 shaves, which means that I would expect that I would have to replace cartridges after ever 2-3 weeks of regular use (ie. shaving every 3 days). If you continue to use the cartridge after the lubristrip has worn out, you will lose some of the benefits of the product's smooth shave. Given the high prices of the replacement cartridges, this could prove to be the factor that deters me from becoming a convert. I would really like the cartridge to last at least month and am disappointed that it has shown signs of wear after only limited use.<br /><br />Overall, I rate the Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power handle 5 stars, because it really does fulfill what it is advertised to do and offers the closest shave a man can get, primarily because of the battery powered micropulses, flexibility, and ergonomic design. Any difficulties maneuvering around the tight spots can be corrected with practice. The Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power cartridge, however, has its drawback and I would only give it 2 stars because of how quickly the lubristrip wears out. The 5-blades and microcomb allow for a smooth shave and remain resilient after repeated uses, but because the lubristrip wears out, the cartridge needs to be trashed.<br /><br />I will probably keep the Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power handle and use it with my Mach3 cartridges (they seem to fit) and only use the more expensive Fusion ProGlide cartridges on special occasions when I need a particularly close shave.
  750. A caregiver shaves my husband and she asked for a Gillette Fusion razor. I bought this one without paying much attention. When it arrived, it took the two of us a little time to figure what the battery was for (DUH!!!) When we realized it was for the trimmer blade she was delighted. Now she can trim his sideburns, his neck in the back, and even the edges of his ears (who knew he had hair on his ears!!!! Oh the joys of getting older) She says it works GREAT!!! I belive her.

  757. I haven't been happy with my shave quality for several years. I went from using an electric to disposables. Disposable razors are less expensive than cartridge systems, but I never realized they aren't as good quality. I've tried a variety of different brands and always tended towards the more expensive of the disposables.<br /><br />It started by reading a few articles online from serious shaving experts. They all recommend a safety razor - but you have to be very careful and it takes much longer. What I noticed was that almost all of them said they use the Gillette Fusion when they travel. Other sites explained that there is a difference between the quality of blades used.<br /><br />So, I gave it a try and was I ever surprised! It really was noticeably smoother than the shave I was getting with regular disposables. My girlfriend loved it. And although I thought the vibrating handle was a gimmick and either wouldn't help or might actually increase the likelihood of being cut, it turned out I was completely wrong! It really does help get a closer shave. I've tried with the vibration switch off and on - and on makes a big difference. I'm really glad I made this change!

  771. This is my second experience with a powered razor which I received via a program run by Gillette. No need for scissors, knifes, etc. Best product packaging yet for a razor handle. The battery falls out when you open the package, so make sure not to loose it in the excitement. Inserting the battery into the compartment on the handle was a breeze although slightly awkward (this is not a simple circle like when screwing in a light bulb, but a slightly awkward battery compartment). Nonetheless, anyone who is minimally handy will figure it out in less then 30 seconds.<br /><br />The experience. Got in the shower and pushed the easy to find power button on the front of the razor. I was surprised when the power symbol lit up in a wonderful hue of blue light. It really made the razor handle look slick and like a product of exceptional quality. The handle immediately started to vibrate. I tried during the same shave using the razor with the micropulses on and then off and did not feel a significant difference.   787. I was fortunate to receive a complimentary Gillette Fusion Proglide Power Razor from Gillette. Had I not received it, I most likely wouldn't have purchased it due to the upfront cost; but now, I do plan on purchasing the refill blades. I have been using store-brand generic six blade razors, and quite honestly, they don't cut it. Pardon the pun, but it's true. With the generics, I would always have to go over my face at least twice (even with a new blade) to ensure a nice, close shave. If I skipped more than a day of shaving, forget it. The generics would be pulling the hair instead of cutting it, and we all know how much that sucks. With the Proglide Power Razor, it was like a hot knife trough butter. For the first shave, I intentionally skipped a day to see how well it did, and was I impressed. There was no tugging and pulling, just a nice smooth shave, after one pass. What a novel idea! After two weeks, it is starting to pull a little, but that is much more than I ever got out of a generic! Although the refill blades are on the expensive side, I will also have to purchase less of them, as they last longer, and give a better shave than the generics anyway. I do plan on continuing the use the Gillette Fusion Powerglide Razor, even after the first cartridge is done.

In addition, if you choose, you can turn the handle on and it vibrates to aid in a smoother and less sensitive shave<br /><br />I typically use an electric razor because of sensitivity, but the GILLETTE FUSION PROGLIDE POWER CARTRIDGE provided me with a smooth and long-lasting shave with minimal irritation. I Received the razor blade and handle free via Gillette as a test and has done very well for me. At this point, I can't speak to the durability of the blades or the life of the blade.
  792. Woah....whoever came up with the concept of adding these vibrating actions to a razor is a genius. I received a free Power Razor from a test-program ran by Gillette and this has changed my shaving experience permanently. I used to shave with razors that I can feel every tug and pull as the hairs are being cut. Not entirely uncomfortable, but still made me cringe. The micropulses, as Gillette calls it, gives me a very smooth cut every time and the vibrating action actually \\"lifts\\" the hairs allowing me to cut as close to my skin as possible without injuring it. I have never had an experience like this before. I would never go back to my old razors; and, trust me, I've experimented with all kinds. This is simple the best. I highly recommend this product!
  793. This battery powered razor gave me the closest shave in years! It even works well in the shower! I was a bit skeptical at first, as I usually use disposable razors, but Gillette has won me over by offering me a free razor through a promotional program. Thank you!!
  794. I received this free via a program run by Gillette. This razor is great. It's easy to handle and isn't awkward to hold. I never have a problem with it slipping out of my hand while shaving. Great product!
  795. I received the power handle free from Gillette, and quickly noticed the soothing effects of the Gillette Fusion PowerGlide Power handle on my face. The slight vibration made for a comfortable and almost therapeutic shave on my easily irritated face. The effects of the constant vibration on my hand is a different story. The vibration quickly became annoying in my hand, almost to the point of becoming uncomfortable. I used the vibrating feature for maybe half of my shave, then had to finish with it powered off. The razor does fit quite comfortably in my hand, and the ergonomic grips allow for an effortless grasp on the shaver.
  796. I was recently sent a Gillette Fusion Proglide, from Gillette. And the Gillette Fusion ProGlide razors are the best razors on the market. They give you the best shave, with no nicks/cuts. They contour to your face, and they last for a long time. It's great for different hair types, as well, I have blonde, light hair, but it work for dark/denser hair as well. My wife bought one for my father a couple of years ago for Christmas, and he couldn't believe how great it worked, and the Gillette Fusion is the only razor he uses now. And, these razors are affordable, and easy to find at the stores. You will go through several cheap disposable razors in length of time you use 1 of these razors. And you won't look like you had a bad encounter with a dull pair of scissors!

  799. This is a great razor that I received for free from a program by Gillette. When I first took it out of the package, I noticed the nice grip on the handle. This is an improvement over my other razor handles as it does feel more ergonomic and easier to grasp.<br /><br />The shave itself is comfortable and easy on my skin. Because it takes fewer strokes and glides over my facial hair easily, I feel the process of shaving with this razor takes up less time than with my previous razors. And definitely, less sensitivity. I also noticed there was less tug and true to its claims, does glide easier over trouble spots like under my chin.<br /><br />For me, a close shave w/ this razor lasts a couple of days before stubbles come out. I'm curious how long the blade will last before I need to replace it. But I do recommend this.
  800. As ad added bonus, I highly recommend the addition of the ProGlide Power Handle.   801. I don't love it.<br /><br />I received my Gillette Fusion ProGlide Lower Handle from Gillette, running a promotion. It's very nice looking, holds the razor cartridge appropriately, and has a &#34;nifty&#34; vibration motor in it...<br /><br />I think it's a failed attempt at what could be really amazing technology. The problem, if you ask me, which you have, is that the handle is very light, and the vibration motor is centrally located, which means not only does the blade vibrate, but the whole handle does. The result is a numbing effect n the hand, so much so that I felt like I couldn't get a safe grip on the handle. The blade didn't feel like it was against my skin, and. I couldn't feel the gratifying feeling of slicing through those coarse little hairs. In fact, by the time I was finished, I couldn't feel anything at all. I have since used the handle without the vibration motor engaged, and I have to say...it's great.take away 80% of its features and you have a great razor handle.

  804. I got the manual version a couple of month ago and was pretty satisfied. But with my thick black beard, 'under the necks' hair is always a problem. I was of the opinion that mechanized handles, such as the electronic toothbrushes, were for the lazy ones among us. But these Fusion power blades turned out to be more than just a mechanized gimmick of the same old same old.<br />Some people have the tendency to get nicks/cuts, which I fortunately don't. Still shaving can be inconvenient. I thought these new blades were much easier to work with, and less inconvenient, to raze through my below the neck hair. The blades also worked well around the jaws, without hurting too much.<br />I find the rear trimmer to be extremely useful as well. Especially for grooming those side-burns and around the stache (if you have one too).<br /><br />Whether I would go for a manual or power blades - Lets see...there is not much of a price difference. power is more convenient. So if you shelling out the money for manuals, just put in a few more bucks for the power.<br /><br />Whether or not mechanized handles are better than electric shavers? I don't know. personally I haven't used any expensive electric shavers and so its hard for me to compare.

  823. When I first saw the Proglide Power Handle come on the market, I dismissed it. I thought, \\"who wants to put a vibrating razor to their face?\\". A friend warned me that he had tried a similar product and it cut him. I recently received a free sample of the Gillette Fusion ProGlide Power handle as part of a program run by Gillette I will chalk up my friend's experience to \\"user error\\", because after trying it for myself, I definitely have an improved opinion. The first thing I needed to do was to get used to the new method of shaving.<br /><br />Instead of taking several shorter strokes to shave, I found the Proglide Power Handle worked best if I used one continuous stroke. This seemed to allow the maximum benefit from the vibration. I actually preferred this shaving method, and it did not cut my face! If you want - though it defeats the benefit of the vibration - you can also use the Proglide as a \\"regular\\" razor, though I liked the vibrations just fine. Either way, the shave was close enough, and lasted all day. The blades also seem to last as least as long as any others I've used, so there is no increased cost for consumables. I haven't gone to buy new blades yet, but a quick Web search puts the prices in line with other blades of similar quality. I would definitely recommend this razor, and will suggest to my friend that he give it another try.

When I first received the Fusion power razor, I admit I was a little skeptical at first. Being a regular Fusion user, I did not honestly see how a powered version of this device could make any significant difference. Boy was I wrong! The multiple blades and vibration lift the hairs prior to trimming, resulting in a much closer shave than obtained using the regular model. The LED lighting on the handle is a nice extra touch, and the device is very comfortable to hold. The only downfall in which I see is that the refills are quite expensive. However, with the closeness of the shave obtained by the device, it may just be worth it!
  850. I got this from a special program from Gillette, but use an electric razor, so I gave it to my wife to use. She uses men's shavers anyway, she says they cut better than women's. she liked it better than her traditional, non-powered razor, but didn't say it was exceptional. Well see how much the blades are and decide if she is going to continue to use it.
  851. 10 years ago, I received one of the first Gillette Fusion razors for my 18th birthday. 10 years later, I participated in a program run by Gillette that gave me the opportunity to try out the latest version of this razor. Safe to say that this thing has come a long way.<br /><br />I'll start my review talking about the handle. In comparison to the previous iteration I owned, not much has changed, but the things that have made me really happy. First, the handle has slimmed down from what it used to be. What this leaves you with a great shape and sized handle that fits perfectly in your hand. They've upgraded the grip on the handle as well, and there is definitely no fear of this bad boy slipping out of you hand. Next, the motor inside has received a significant boost. I used to think the vibration was a gimmick, but after years of shaving with one of these razors, I can safely say it gives you a very close shave. Overall, the changes to the handle were slight, but left me with a very satisfied feeling over the improvements.<br /><br />As for the actual cartridge, it's another winner in my book. It seems like Gillette comes out with a new version every year or so, so it's hard to tell if anything is really being improved. However, with this iteration I noticed a major change in how well it shaved and how little it irritated my skin. My big problem area is under my chin on my neck and right along the jawline. All the other cartridges I've used have left me with knicks and this feeling of stubble I couldn't get rid of. When I used this new blade, I didn't have any of those problems. I have been going around trimming my beard down and not shaving for the longest time because I dreaded using a razor, but this one may actually get me back in to shaving.<br /><br />The one negative I can say is that the replacement heads are outrageously priced. This will definitely be a factor for me in deciding on when to replace my cartridges and how often I shave. Also in my experience, the cartridges are interchangeable between the different Gillette Fusion handles, so unless yours has broken or is very old I wouldn't recommend buying this one expecting a significant upgrade. All in all though, this razor gives a very close shave and has come a long way from the previous version I owned.
  852. I got my hands on the Fusion Proglide Power Razor through a program run by Gillette. I haven't owned one before, but I was really impressed by the shaving experience after using this product.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1. Makes it easy to get a nice clean shave. Works like a charm!<br />2. I love the auto shutdown (safety) feature.<br />3. The vibration makes the shaving experience effortless.<br />4. I've used the old Fusion ProGlide (Manual), and body redesign has made the product way more comfortable to handle. I love the way this fits in my hand.<br /><br />Cons:<br />1. The vibration seems to be a little too strong to my liking. It works great, but I can't use it continuously for more than a minute.<br /><br />Verdict:<br />I would definitely recommend this product to a friend. Totally worth the buck!
  853. I received this razor about a month ago for free through a program run by Gillette. I must say, I never would have bought the razor myself, as I was not unhappy with my razor at the time (Gillette Mach 3). I'm glad I was part of the free trial program, though!<br /><br />The first time I used the razor was a bit weird due to the different handle than I was used to and the vibrating feature. It's just strange to have a razor vibrate in your hand and on your face! But let me tell you, I was very happy with the shave. The handle took 2-3 uses to get fully used to, but it's possible I may never go back to a normal razor again. Shaving every-other day as I normally do, I found the Fusion Power to provide a more comfortable shave than the Mach 3. There was less irritation, and the shave was closer than with the Mach 3 (whether this is from the handle or the increased blades, I can't be positive). I also let my \\"scratchies\\" (as my 3-y/o daughter calls them) go for 4 days, when they are officially \\"soft\\" rather than so scratchy. Quite long! At that point, I almost wouldn't consider shaving with the Mach 3 without first trimming. With the Fusion Power, I had no irritation, no blood spots, nothing to complain about! I was very impressed.<br /><br />In short, the handle vibrations take a bit to get used to, but the shave is extremely comfortable and close! I would recommend the razor to anyone!

It is substantial and solid, not like the cheap blades that are so common. I will continue to use this razor and recommend it for a smooth, easy shave.

While I do not feel as though I received a better shave do to the vibration, it does feel good on the hand while holding it. Overall I would recommend this handle as it does feel great in the hand.

The precision trimmer is definitely helpful in getting to the hard to get area of under the nose and for straightening out the sideburns.
